ranked_diseases.explanation: Perfect match with Case 1 reference - all six phenotypic features (postaxial polydactyly, clinodactyly, brachydactyly, reduced visual acuity, nyctalopia, and mild intellectual disability) are consistent with BBS5.
Classic BBS presenting with polydactyly, retinal dystrophy (nyctalopia, reduced visual acuity), intellectual disability, and limb abnormalities. BBS1 is the most common form.
Another BBS subtype that can present with identical features including polydactyly, retinal degeneration, cognitive impairment, and digital anomalies.
BBS4 can present with the same constellation of features including postaxial polydactyly, retinopathy, and intellectual disability.
Shares postaxial polydactyly with BBS but typically lacks retinal involvement; however, some overlap exists and retinal features may develop later.
Can present with retinal dystrophy and intellectual disability but typically lacks polydactyly; included due to overlapping retinal and cognitive features.
